moves.1. e4 c5: Clearing the black diagonal in preperation for Bg2
moves.4... e6 5. dxc5 Qa5+: Classic beginner's mistake, "don't bring out the Queen too early", the rest of this game demonstrates why.
moves.6. c3 Qxc5 7. Bd3 Nf6 8. Be3 Qc7 9. O-O: Now we're all tucked up in our castles, but look at the difference in development and space control.  Brett's bishops dominate the board and his e-pawn is about to become the pivot for subsequent attacks.
moves.10. e5 Nd5 11. Bd4 Nc6 12. Bc5 Re8 13. R: At this point I really should have played Ne5
moves.13... b6: But instead tried to dislodge the bishop
moves.14. Bd6: Not the result I'd hoped for
moves.14... Qd8 15. Bc4 Nf4 16. Nbd2 Bf8 17. N: Still want to shift the bishop, but don't want his knight in it's place!
Opening up the white king's defence like that looks like a bad move, Qh6 would have been a more substantial threat
moves.20... f5 21. exf6 e.p. Nxf6 22. Nxf6+: Now I have a knight and bishop to deal with, along with the impending threat of the half open e file and Brett's rooks.  Why did I have to move that Queen??!
moves.22... Kg7 23. g5 Bb7: The pawn on f2 looks like a potential weak point - I line up the bishop and prepare for either Qf1 or Rf2.  Which of these would be better,  or is there another possibility altogether?
moves.25. Rad1: This puts pressure on my e-pawn, need to come up with something good NOW
moves.25... a6: This isn't it.  Brett flings his bishop into the fray, I'm running out of possiblities.
moves.26. Bxe6 Re7 27. Nh5+: Rg8 may have been a better move, but by this time I think it would just be delaying the inevitable.
moves.27... gxh5 28. Qf6#: Check mate and cheers, mate.  Remember now, children, leave the Queen moves till last unless there's a VERY good reason not to.
